nodes.bodyText: Is there a reason these fields are being deleted rather than just no longer using them?
As I said this is an adaption of a previous patch that was present in 1.15.2, I can add them back in if you would like, although they do have no use.
Re-added

There is no reason to be changing the formatting of vanilla classes (such as moving the bracket to the next line). And the formatting should match the rest of the file, which means that for patches brackets go on the same line not on the next one (there are a lot of cases below where you are putting them on the next one).
Ah thanks, this is my first time contributing so I was not sure.
Fixed
I am not actually positive on the stance of Forge Registry vs Vanilla Registry use in patches, but is there a reason this is using the vanilla registry instead of the Forge Registry for biomes?
Looking at it closer, it appears that the forge registries do not have an option to get the numerical id of a biome, correct me if I'm wrong.  This is why vanilla registries are required here.
They... do, but that requires a cast to the actual underlying type (ForgeRegistry) rather than the field type of IForgeRegistry

and I do not prefer the ForgeRegistry cast hack
as it ties things to one implementation

tterrag
Not sure if extra whitespace in a patch is a problem or not, since forge prefers patches to be as small as possible. But it's probably fine.
You need to add the Forge method markers. Additionally please check that this is at the end of the file.
This is at the end of the file, what are Forge method markers @OrionDevelopment ?

Look at other patched vanilla classes which have methods that have been added by forge.
There are two comments: ///////// FORGE START /////////// and /////////// FORGE END //////////// or something in that direction.
These enclose the methods that forge added to that class, and allow us to easily identify the methods which are not from the vanilla code base and are very handy during porting.
Ah, makes sense.  Done.
Remove the not needed whiteline.
Sure, will do

You could probably get rid of this line as well.
Just use type.ordinal() in the couple of places you are using it.
I am not quite sure as to what you mean @OrionDevelopment ?  Which line?

See this line 14 of your patch file?. It defines the variable idx as type.ordinal().
And is then only used todo look ups 3 times.
This variable as such is not really needed, and can be removed to reduce the patch size.
Ah, will remove

Are these original fields still in use?
If not: Put a  @Deprecated in front of them (on the same line) and a comment behind them referencing their replacement (also on the same line)
Eventhough these fields might be private, if vanilla code becomes unused by forge changes. We should keep track of this. Not just for people using the code, but also for porters who port the patch in the future. It is then always good to know what happens with a field.
Do not remove the field since that can also cause issue. As I said a @Deprecated and a comment should suffice.

nodes.bodyText: Sure, will do

nodes.bodyText:
Please remove this whiteline.
It is not needed.
Sure, will do
This method can probably be renamed to getWeightedBiome and just return the Biome, since the weight value is only needed here and not in BiomeLayer.
True, but it may be useful for other things that we haven't thought about to use this method and get the weight

Even if the weight value is useful for other processes, those other processes should probably be handled within BiomeManager or in other processes called from it, and not done within BiomeLayer, which would also require further patching it. At the point that this method returns, it should only be the Biome, since that it all that is consequential in BiomeLayer.

@Xerousso You can leave it like this.
It does not hurt to have it return BiomeEntry instead of biome.
Please add a comment stating why they are deprecated and what their replacement is, if any.
LexManos and diesieben07 said its pointless to do a comment or deprecate these at all as they are private fields.
See the other mods on how todo these. Most notably missing is a way to disable a given testmod.
Done.
